title: HEO looks to expand satellite imaging beyond low Earth orbit
summary:
An Australian company that is a leader in taking images of spacecraft in low Earth orbit is seeking to widen its aperture to monitor higher orbits, and even beyond.
The post HEO looks to expand satellite imaging beyond low Earth orbit appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Australian company is a leader in taking images of spacecraft in low Earth orbit. It is seeking to widen its aperture to monitor higher orbits, and even beyond. HEO has conducted 4,000 “missions,” which is what the company calls a flyby by an imaging satellite. HEO estimates that at least 30 asteroids more than 19 meters across will pass ‘really close’ to the GEO belt. Such imagery could be used for scientific purposes or even resource extraction. “This is an opportunity that is too good to miss,” HEO says.

title: The spreadsheet behind the Golden Dome sticker shock
summary:
Todd Harrison demonstrates the ‘Defense Futures Simulator’ that calculated eye-watering missile defense costs — and invites critics to prove him wrong with their own numbers.
The post The spreadsheet behind the Golden Dome sticker shock appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: President Trump in May said it would cost $175 billion over three years. Congressional Budget Office projected between $161 billion and $542 billion over two decades. Todd Harrison’s “robust all-threat defense’ scenario came in at $3.6 trillion. The cost of Golden Dome should not exceed a quarter of the U.S. defense budget. Harrison pinpointed the Trump administration’s focus on boost-phase intercept as a key reason costs balloon to such heights. If the goal shifted to midcourse defense, interceptors would have more time to fire and coast through space to reach their targets.

title: At IAC, global space cooperation meets American space dominance
summary:
As the global space community gathered to discuss exploration and cooperation, one theme emerged: how countries are adapting to changes in policies, budgets and leadership at NASA.
The post At IAC, global space cooperation meets American space dominance appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: The International Astronautical Congress was held in Sydney this week. It was the first opportunity for leaders of space agencies to meet with NASA's acting administrator. NASA and Sean Duffy emphasized U.S. leadership in space, almost aggressively. Many space agencies have been scrambling to adjust to changes at NASA. Australia signed a framework agreement with the United States to deepen cooperation in space and aeronautics. At the same time, the Australian government announced it would begin negotiations with ESA on a cooperative agreement. That could allow Australian companies and organizations to participate directly in ESA programs, giving Australia a status similar to Canada's within the agency.

title: Wide-field surveys versus precise infrared observations: how Rubin compares to JWST
summary:
Earlier this year, the new Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile officially began scientific operations,…
The post Wide-field surveys versus precise infrared observations: how Rubin compares to JWST appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Earlier this year, the new Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile officially began scientific operations, becoming the world’s largest and most advanced ground-based telescope. Meanwhile, situated at the L2 Lagrange point is the James Webb Space Telescope. Both telescopes represent different technological solutions to mapping and analyzing the cosmos. Together they are poised to reveal untold information about our universe. The Rubin Science Platform (RSP) provides cloud-based data access, eliminating the need for researchers to download massive datasets locally. Nightly operations generate approximately 20 terabytes of data, processed through automated systems. Real-time processing capabilities can generate up to 10 million alerts per night when changes to existing objects or the introduction of new objects are detected. The Rubin Observatory’s survey approach generates approximately 7.3 petabytes of data annually. JWST produces roughly 350 times less data than Rubin, but focuses on precision observations. Rubin functions as a wide-field reconnaissance system, systematically cataloging approximately 20 billion galaxies, 17 billion stars, and millions of asteroids across the southern sky. NASA's next round of space flights will take place between September 30, 2025 and April 11, 2025. The space agency's next series of flights will also take place in 2023, 2024 and 2025. NASA's next fleet of spaceflights will be the largest since the space shuttle program began in 1986.

title: How America fell behind China in the lunar space race—and how it can catch back up
summary: Thanks to some recent reporting, we've found a potential solution to the Artemis blues.
detailed_news: NASA's interim administrator, Sean Duffy, has been giving interviews and speeches around the world. Many people within the space industry, and even at NASA, acknowledge that the US space agency appears to be holding a losing hand. The purpose of this article is to articulate how NASA ended up falling behind China, and how the Western world could realistically retake the lead. NASA lost a decade, spending billions of dollars a year developing "exploration" systems for humans. The program's only achievement was to enrich the legacy space contractors. The new leader of NASA, Jim Bridenstine, managed to ditch the Journey to Mars and establish a lunar program. SpaceX's Starship program is not ready to land humans on the Moon. The company's goal is to send humans to Mars. The complexity of the mission will require multiple launches from Earth. Blue Origin's Mark 1 lander could be the answer, but it's not rated for humans. Blue Origin has a contract with NASA to develop the Mark 2 lander. The Mark 2 will not be ready until sometime in the 2030s. A modified version of the Mark 1 lander could be part of an architecture to land humans on the Moon this decade. It would involve "multiple" landers to carry crew down to the lunar surface.

title: Will Pentagon procurement reforms really stick this time?
summary:
A mix of executive orders, new contracting approaches and closer ties between defense leaders and investors has some experts believing this latest reform drive may be different from the past.
The post Will Pentagon procurement reforms really stick this time? appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: U.S. Space Force procurement chief tours Blue Origin and Vast Space. The outreach to the private sector comes as the Pentagon is scrambling to overhaul its procurement system. President Donald Trump signed an executive order pressing the department to expand its use of commercial technology. Congress is weighing companion legislation that would cut red tape for defense programs. The Space Force has a $40 billion fiscal 2026 request fueled by the Golden Dome missile-defense program. Instead of commissioning a handful of bespoke satellites, the Space Force plans to buy fleets of smaller spacecraft from multiple vendors. The logic is redundancy. If one satellite is disabled in orbit, dozens more can pick up the slack. Space station developer Vast believes commercial infrastructure could one day provide the backbone for a U.S. military presence in space. The Space Force’s plans for rapid innovation hinge on an industrial base that is both financially sound and broad enough to support those aspirations. The lower tiers of the supply chain remain fragile, Teague noted. The challenge will be sustaining momentum. If Congress waters down reform bills or if the Pentagon reverts to its cautious habits, the window could close. Purdy is pressing his officers to get out of the office, into factories and onto venture capital pitch decks. “The Space Force is creating massive opportunities for companies,” Teague says.

The post University of Western Australia unveils optical ground network appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: TeraNet is comprised of three interconnected optical ground stations. It is the first operational optical ground station network in the Southern Hemisphere. TeraNet will enhance Australia’s reputation as a trusted and capable partner in the global space sector. The network will enhance our ability to connect with spacecraft and future lunar missions.

The company is moving ahead with its full-scale Nyx cargo vehicle. Nyx is slated for a demonstration mission to the International Space Station in 2028. Growing number of megaconstellations destined for low-Earth orbit will require “real-time information sharing across all of our agencies,” NASA says. summary:
An agreement to study a private astronaut mission using an Orion spacecraft is a step by Lockheed Martin in efforts to offer the spacecraft as a service.
The post Private mission study a step toward offering Orion as a service appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Lockheed Martin is studying flying a mission in Orion beyond Earth orbit to perform biomedical research. The Twin Astra mission would be modeled on NASA’s Twins Study from a decade ago. The mission concept is still in its earliest phases. Lockheed announced in July that it is studying how to offer Orion as a commercial service. The Orion service module is provided by the European Space Agency under a barter agreement with NASA. Lockheed has been talking with both ESA and Airbus Defence and Space about how they could work together under a services approach. Lockheed is also examining alternatives to the Space Launch System for flying Orion.

title: ViaSat-3 F2 satellite arrives in Florida ahead of late October launch
summary: The spacecraft will launch onboard a United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 551 rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. It’s built on Boeing’s 702MP+ satellite bus.
detailed_news: The ViaSat-3 Flight 2 spacecraft arrived in Florida in the early morning hours of Tuesday. This six-ton (more than 13,000 lbs) satellite is the second in a three-vehicle series. Its planned launch in late October onboard a United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 551 rocket. Viasat said this second Ka-band satellite will more than double the bandwidth capacity. Viasat has not publicly announced which rocket will carry its ViaSat-3 F3 satellite. The spacecraft, which will serve the Asia-Pacific region, was originally scheduled to launch on an Ariane 6 rocket. Viasat recorded a reduction to the carrying value of the satellites of approximately $1.67 billion in fiscal year 2024.

title: What Germany’s $41B investment in space could mean for Europe
summary:
Germany will invest 35 billion euros ($41.1 billion) into defense space technologies within the next five years — an unprecedented amount for any European country. The decision, made in response to rising tensions with Russia, has been hailed a “watershed moment” for the German and European space sector, and experts say could spur a new […]
The post What Germany’s $41B investment in space could mean for Europe appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Germany will invest 35 billion euros ($41.1 billion) into defense space technologies within the next five years. The decision, made in response to rising tensions with Russia, has been hailed a “watershed moment” for the German and European space sector. Experts say could spur a new era in European space cooperation. The European Union, which is not directly linked to ESA, also has its own space budget. The EU’s lengthy procurement cycle and preference for established prime contractors has been criticized by the European space small- and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups. Meyer-Brunswick said that the new German space defense budget will finally allow the newcomers their chance to grow and shine. Tereza Pultarova is a London-based science and technology journalist and video producer. She covers European space developments for SpaceNews.com. title: How time series data is fueling the final frontier
summary:
When we think of space exploration, we picture towering rockets, satellites orbiting Earth and astronaut footprints on the moon. However, behind these grand achievements lies an unsung hero: time series data. Today, as physical AI (or AI that interacts with and learns from the physical world) plays a growing role in space missions, the ability […]
The post How time series data is fueling the final frontier appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Time series is a record of how things change over time. In aerospace, that means temperatures, voltages, pressure, positioning and thousands of other readings streaming from sensors every second. Time series powers everything from trajectory tracking and fuel monitoring to successful docking operations. Earth observation, deep-space navigation and even unlocking discoveries on Mars all depend on physical AI that’s making decisions. Every major leap in space exploration relies on time series data. Time series has long been the quiet workhorse of aerospace. Now, with the rise of physical AI, it’s moving to the forefront. The future of space exploration depends on how well we harness it. title: Advancing Europe’s quantum secure communications from space
summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) has signed a €50 million contract with aerospace company Thales Alenia Space to begin the preliminary design phase of the Security And cryptoGrAphic (SAGA) mission. This agreement enables SAGA to continue to its preliminary design review, marking a relevant step towards establishing secure, space-based communications using quantum technologies.
detailed_news: ESA has signed a €50 million contract with aerospace company Thales Alenia Space to begin the preliminary design phase of the Security And cryptoGrAphic (SAGA) mission. SAGA, developed by ESA, aims to demonstrate quantum key distribution (QKD) via satellites.

title: Maxar retires its name, rebrands as Vantor and Lanteris
summary:
The Maxar name is disappearing from the space industry as two successor companies emerge with distinct identities: Maxar Intelligence will now operate as Vantor, and Maxar Space Systems will go by Lanteris
The post Maxar retires its name, rebrands as Vantor and Lanteris appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Maxar’s satellite manufacturing arm was hit hard by a global slump in commercial GEO communications satellites. Order volumes fell as operators faced excess capacity, shifting customer demands and the rise of low Earth orbit (LEO) constellations. The company shifted its focus toward government work and smaller satellites.

The satellite will undergo various functional tests, solar array checks and will be fuelled for its life in orbit. The exact launch date is to be announced in the coming weeks.

title: Cassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean
summary: Scientists digging through data collected by the Cassini spacecraft have found new complex organic molecules spewing from Saturn’s moon Enceladus. This is a clear sign that complex chemical reactions are taking place within its underground ocean. Some of these reactions could be part of chains that lead to even more complex, potentially biologically relevant molecules.
detailed_news: Scientists have found new complex organic molecules spewing from Saturn’s moon Enceladus. This is a clear sign that complex chemical reactions are taking place within its underground ocean. Some of these reactions could be part of chains that lead to even more complex, potentially biologically relevant molecules. This discovery further strengthens the case for a dedicated European Space Agency (ESA) mission to orbit and land on the moon. Discoveries from Cassini are valuable for planning a future ESA mission dedicated to Enceladus. The plan is to fly through the jets and even land on the moon's south polar terrain to collect samples. A mission that takes measurements directly from the moon’s surface, seeking out signs of life, would offer Europe a front seat in Solar System science.
